title: [EPIC] [Community Ownership] Transfer community ownership

milestone.description:
**1. Finish anything that wasn't completed in the previous 0.14 cycle**

- And fix bugs as usual. We need to keep tech. debt at a roughly fixed level as we grow out functionality, can't let it accumulate! ;-)

**2. Complete initial airdrop functionality**
- Airdrop history screens
- Ability to airdrop based on in-Community activity (No. of msg, No. msg in time range, joining a community, length of community membership)  Ability to combine multiple attributes into an airdrop
- Ability to token gate airdrops
- Live airdrop gas estimation when setting up airdrop

**3. Token import functionality**
- Ability for a community Owner to import ERC-20 and NFT tokens, to later be airdropped or retailed

**4. Admin functionality enhancements**
- Ability to mark a token gated channel as 'hidden', only visible to community members with the requisite tokens
- optional service to once a month auto-kick all members who haven't been online for between 30 and 60 days (e.g. auto-kick members whose profile information like Name, Avatar, etc... can no longer be fetched)

**5. QR scanner**
- Needed for private key transfer
- Ethereum key QRs (send modal triggered)
- User Share URL in a QR (opens user profile dialogue) 
- Community and Channel inside Community URL in QRs (takes user to Community or Channel in Community)

**6. Chat functionality enhancements**
- Introduce @channel as a new type of global @ mention.  This @ mention only @ mention's everyone who has posted a message in a channel in the last 30 days 

**7. Binaries over Waku**
- Improve transfer of binaries over waku via splitting into chunks https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/issues/9923
- Posting of small files (max size somewhere in the region of 1 to 2mb).  Requires above item before going live


**--- Wallet Team ---**

1. Total balance graphs for 'All accounts' and each individual account

2. Advanced transaction signing

body:
Nowadays, anyone with access to a community's private key is considered a control node. To import a community, one needs to transfer this private key across clients, which is problematic for many reasons.

Community ownership should be tokenized, i.e., bound to the owner of the Owner Token. To accomplish this, community updates should be signed not by the community's private key, but by the signer specified by the holder of the Owner Token.

- How is community ownership transferred?
Transfer the Owner Token to another account. Once this account receives the Owner Token, it needs to set a new signer using `ownerToken.setSigner(...)`.
- How do clients know who the signer of the community updates should be?
If the community has an Owner Token assigned, then the signer is identified by `ownerToken.getSigner()`. If not, the signer is the community itself.
- Why is the concept of `setSigner/getSigner` necessary? Couldn't we simply check the signature against the holder of the Owner Token?
This concept enables the establishment of a control node without needing to import the wallet containing the Owner Token.
- How can clients trust the Owner Token address bound to a given community?
The Owner Token must be deployed by the community address and only the first deployment is valid. This is to prevent malicious owners from deploying multiple Owner Tokens with potentially harmful intentions in the future. Furthermore, the contract's bytecode will be provided by Status and must be validated by clients.
- How will Status provide the contract's bytecode?
The contract's bytecode will be deployed within the official status-go repository.

Tasks:
- [ ] extend Owner Token contract with `setSigner/getSigner` API
- [ ] deploy Owner Token through community address
- [ ] obtain first deployed Owner Token and get the signer
- [ ] validate Owner Token contract against known bytecode
- [ ] enable community updates to be signed by anyone

Spikes:
- [x] #11371
